original_table_html:
Pricing Situation Description
Product line pricing Setting prices across an entire product line
Optional-product pricing Pricing optional or accessory products sold with the main product
Captive-product pricing Pricing products that must be used with the main product
By-product pricing Pricing low-value by-products to get rid of or make money on them
Product bundle pricing Pricing bundles of products sold together
summary_markdown: This table outlines five distinct pricing situations related to product strategy. Product line pricing involves setting prices for a range of related products. Optional-product pricing focuses on the pricing of accessories or add-ons that accompany a main product. Captive-product pricing addresses the pricing of essential complementary products required for the main product's use. By-product pricing deals with the strategic pricing of secondary, often low-value, outputs generated during the production of a primary product, either for disposal or profit. Finally, product bundle pricing involves setting a single price for a package of multiple products sold together. These strategies represent different approaches to managing pricing across a company's product offerings and their associated components or combinations.
